items.title: U.S. and Russia reportedly draft peace plan for Ukraine
Advocates calling for improved pain management for IUD insertions in B.C.
items.summary_auto: For some, IUD insertion is no problem. For others, it’s extremely painful.

items.title: Europe, Ukraine must be involved in U.S.-Russia peace plan circulating, European diplomats say
items.summary_auto: Ukraine and Europe must be consulted on any efforts to end Russia's invasion of its neighbour, top European diplomats said Thursday, as reports circulated about a U.S.-Russian proposal to end the war at a time when corruption allegations have rattled Ukraine's government.

items.title: $10M deal gives Winnipeg developer control of land from First Nation he advised
items.summary_auto: A former golf course north of Winnipeg purchased with money Peguis First Nation received as reparation for broken treaty promises is now mostly in the hands of a property developer who used to advise the band and its real estate trust.

items.title: Dartmouth Community Fridge spends thousands to keep up with demand
items.summary_auto: A Dartmouth, volunteer-run organization says it's now buying nearly $6,000 worth of food each month for people to take for free from its community fridge.

items.title: Trump to meet NYC mayor-elect Mamdani at White House on Friday
items.summary_auto: U.S. President Donald Trump said he will meet New York City mayor-elect Zohran Mamdani at the White House on Friday in what would be the first meeting of the Republican leader with the democratic socialist who won this month's mayoral election.

items.title: Government seeks to retroactively change law, potentially avoiding paying veterans over federal error
Why the U.S. Justice Department and Congress may battle over redaction of Epstein files
items.summary_auto: When it comes to the Epstein files, there are solid reasons to withold certain information from the public, experts say. However, there are also grey areas that could cause disputes between lawmakers and the U.S. Department of Justice, and which could frustrate those seeking as much information as possible about the case.

items.title: She lost 5 children during the war in Gaza — now she’s raising 36 grandkids in a tent
items.summary_auto: Reda Aliwa, 60, is caring for her 36 grandchildren in Gaza City after five of her own children were killed this September. Statistics suggest there are some 40,000 children in Gaza who’ve lost one or more parents, resulting in what one Palestinian organization has called “the largest orphan crisis in modern history.”

items.title: Do kids still want toys? Toy stores are struggling, but don't just blame screens
items.summary_auto: In the age of screens, amid reports of retail stores struggling and studies suggesting that all kids want for Christmas are Robux, what does the future hold for the toy industry?

items.title: ‘Obviously cruel policies’: U.K.’s proposed asylum rules draw pushback from critics
items.summary_auto: Tough new asylum rules proposed by Britain’s Labour government have sparked debate not just in Britain, but within the governing party as critics accuse the leadership of donning a hard-right mantle to counter a rise in the polls by the populist anti-immigration party, Reform UK.

items.title: Camera catches mystery man saluting outside home where Canadian flag's been left the last 8 Remembrance Days
items.summary_auto: Every Remembrance Day since Bailey Binns-Franchetto moved into her wartime home in the St. Mary's neighbourhood of Kitchener, Ont., eight years ago, someone has planted a flag on the front lawn. This year, a security camera caught a glimpse of a man, and Binns-Franchetto hopes to find out who he is.

items.title: In the shadow of the Himalayas, this town is sinking, a casualty of the past and the present
items.summary_auto: Almost three years ago, hundreds of residents in Joshimath, India, were forced to leave after deep cracks appeared in the walls of some 800 homes because the ground was sinking around them. The town's location, climate change and heavy construction are being blamed.

items.title: Are toy stores dying? Why big-box chains are struggling even as toy sales climb
items.summary_auto: In the age of screens, amid reports of retail stores struggling and studies suggesting that all kids want for Christmas are Robux, what does the future hold for the toy industry?

items.title: Governor General's Award-winning playwright Ian Ross, 57, 'left a lot of love behind': artistic director
items.summary_auto: Manitoba’s theatre community is mourning the sudden death of Ian Ross, an award-winning Métis-Ojibway playwright and storyteller who was a mainstay of the city's theatre scene. He died Wednesday at the age of 57.

items.title: 8-year-old girl who died in Vancouver balcony fall remembered as 'beautiful soul'
items.summary_auto: Family members and more than 150 supporters gathered in Squamish, B.C., to remember eight-year-old Gandom Taheri.

items.title: Head of civil service defends Carney’s ethics screen at House committee
Haitian Montrealers on cloud nine after Haiti’s shock FIFA World Cup qualification
items.summary_auto: Despite domestic turmoil and the lack of a usable home stadium, Haiti’s national men’s soccer team has brought pride to Haitian diasporas worldwide, including a relatively large one in Montreal.

items.title: What science says about this year's flu shot
items.summary_auto: Only about four in 10 Canadians get the flu shot each year, but doctors say that’s not enough. Here’s why the vaccine still matters, who benefits most and what the latest research shows.

items.title: B.C.-incorporated crypto exchange Cryptomus appeals record $177M penalty
items.summary_auto: A cryptocurrency firm incorporated in British Columbia is appealing a penalty of almost $177 million issued by Canada's anti-money-laundering agency last month.

items.title: Mount Semeru erupts in Indonesia, prompting evacuations
items.summary_auto: Indonesia's Mount Semeru erupted, covering nearby villages in ash and prompting evacuations of more than 300 residents of the most at-risk villages.

items.title: Ontario education minister eyes more possible school board takeovers as Bill 33 passes
items.summary_auto: Ontario Education Minister Paul Calandra says a newly passed bill granting him more powers to take control of school boards is a start, but not the end, of changes to education governance.

items.title: Police discover explosive device inside Prince George, B.C., home
items.summary_auto: Prince George RCMP has evacuated several residences in the 1600 block of 8th Avenue after finding an explosive device in a home during a Controlled Drugs and Substance Act search warrant.

items.title: Alberta premier confirms plans to allow physicians to work in both public and private health care systems
items.summary_auto: Alberta Premier Danielle Smith has confirmed her government's intention to allow physicians flexibility to work in both the public and private health care systems.

items.title: Alberta premier confirms plans to allow surgeons to work in both public and private health care systems
